description: Borrowed from Latin reclīnāre (“to bend back”). Compare decline, incline.

entries.meaning: A mechanism for lowering the back of a seat to support a less upright position; Also, the action of lowering the back using such a mechanism.
examples: To gain a little more space, airlines are turning to a new generation of seats that use lighter materials and less padding, moving the magazine pocket above the tray table and even reducing or eliminating the recline in seats.

verbs.description: recline (third-person singular simple present reclines, present participle reclining, simple past and past participle reclined)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to lean back; to bend back.
(transitive) To put in a resting position.
examples: She reclined her arms on the table and sighed.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To put oneself in a resting position.
